text: I am kind of annoyed at how much it's being mentioned these days. It's really popular in VC-consultant-analyst circles because it sounds really great on a strategy deck because all of the things that are really appealing, we'll talk about lower customer acquisition costs, higher attach rates to different products, talk about higher retention across different services, the ease of cross-selling and upselling. All of these things sound great, but in reality, a lot of those benefits don't pan out.
speaker: Kevin Aluwi
context: Lenny asks Kevin about his thoughts on super apps, given that many US companies like Uber and Twitter are trying to become super apps. Kevin explains his mixed views on the super app strategy, arguing that while super apps sound appealing to VCs and analysts because they promise benefits like lower customer acquisition costs and higher retention, these theoretical advantages often don't materialize in practice.
text_ko: 요즘 이 얘기가 너무 자주 나와서 약간 짜증나요. VC·컨설턴트·애널리스트들(VC-consultant-analyst circles) 사이에서 엄청 인기인데, 전략 데크(strategy deck)에 넣으면 정말 근사하게 들리거든요. 매력적으로 들리는 이야기들 — 고객 획득 비용(customer acquisition costs)은 낮아 보이고, 제품별 추가 구매율(attach rates)은 높아 보이고, 다양한 서비스에서의 유지율(retention)도 좋아 보이고, 교차 판매(cross-selling)나 업셀링(upselling)도 쉽다고 말하죠. 다 좋은 말들이지만, 현실에서는 그런 혜택들이 실제로는 많이 안 나오는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 最近到处都在提这个概念，我都有点烦了。在VC、咨询师、分析师这些圈子里特别火，因为放在战略汇报(strategy deck)里听起来特别棒——什么客户获取成本(customer acquisition costs)更低啦，不同产品的关联销售率(attach rates)更高啦，各种服务的用户留存(retention)更好啦，交叉销售(cross-selling)和向上销售(upselling)更容易啦。这些听起来都很美好，但实际上呢，很多好处根本就实现不了。
text_es: Me molesta un poco lo mucho que se está hablando de esto últimamente. Está súper de moda en los círculos de capital de riesgo, consultores y analistas porque suena padrísimo en una presentación de estrategia - hablas de menores costos de adquisición de clientes, mayores tasas de adopción de diferentes productos, mejor retención en distintos servicios, lo fácil que es hacer venta cruzada y upselling. Todo eso suena increíble, pero la realidad es que muchos de esos beneficios no se materializan.
key_sentence: Many benefits sound great, but in reality, they don't pan out.

text: And so I think this kind of illustrates the importance of having these unifying concepts that are easy for customers to think about the multiple different services. It's not as simple as just saying, oh, we have a lot of engagement, we have a lot of eyeballs at a service. And then you have a super app that makes sense for customers.
speaker: Kevin Aluwi
context: Lenny is asking Kevin to elaborate on why super apps don't work as well as expected. Kevin is explaining that customers need a mental framework to understand why different services belong together in one app. He uses examples from Gojek where services connected to drivers made sense to customers (ride-hailing, food delivery, package delivery), but other services like mobile top-ups didn't because they lacked this unifying concept.
vocabulary_highlights: we have a lot of eyeballs
text_ko: 그래서 이런 점이 고객들이 여러 다른 서비스를 떠올릴 때 이해하기 쉬운 통합 개념(unifying concepts)을 갖는 것의 중요성을 잘 보여준다고 생각해요. 단순히 참여도(engagement)가 높고 서비스에 트래픽(eyeballs)이 많다고 해서 바로 고객에게 와닿는 슈퍼앱(super app)이 되는 건 아니에요.
text_zh: 所以我觉得这个例子很好地说明了一点，就是你得有一些统一的概念，让客户能够很容易地理解你的各种不同服务。这事儿可不像说"哎呀我们用户活跃度很高，流量也很大"，然后就能做出一个让用户觉得有意义的超级应用(super app)那么简单。
text_es: Entonces, creo que esto demuestra lo importante que es tener conceptos unificadores que les faciliten a los clientes entender los distintos servicios. No es tan sencillo como decir "ay, tenemos mucho engagement, tenemos muchos eyeballs en un servicio" y ya tienes una súper app que tenga sentido para los clientes.
key_sentence: Unifying concepts help customers understand multiple services better.

text: But I wish I did have to start there because we actually started as a very scrappy company where we were by far the underfunded player and without brand. We probably would've never gotten to escape velocity beyond that scrappy stage, we've maintained our leadership in Indonesia through a lot of the things that we actually did on the brand side to give you a sense of how scrappy we had to be in competition.
speaker: Kevin Aluwi
context: Lenny asks Kevin about the importance of brand for startups and how to prioritize it. Kevin explains that while he opened by discussing Gojek's massive scale, he actually prefers to emphasize how they started as an extremely underfunded company. He argues that brand was crucial to their survival and growth, allowing them to compete against much better-funded competitors who had raised over 100 times more capital than Gojek in the early days.
text_ko: 사실 그 지점부터 시작했어야 했으면 좋았을 텐데요. 저희는 정말 자금도 부족하고 브랜드도 없는, 완전 허술한 회사로 시작했거든요. 그 허술한 단계에서 벗어나 탈출 속도(escape velocity)를 얻지 못했을 가능성이 컸을 거예요. 지금 인도네시아에서 리더십을 유지하고 있는 건, 경쟁에서 얼마나 허술하게라도 버텨야 했는지를 보여주는 브랜드 측면에서 저희가 실제로 해온 여러 활동들 덕분이에요.
text_zh: 不过我还真希望我们是从那种状态开始的，因为我们当时确实是个特别能折腾的小公司，资金远远不够，也没什么品牌影响力。要不是那种拼劲儿，我们可能永远都突破不了那个小打小闹的阶段。我们能在印尼保持领先地位，很大程度上靠的就是品牌方面下的功夫。你们可以想象一下，在竞争中我们得有多能折腾才行。
text_es: Pero ojalá hubiéramos tenido que empezar desde ahí porque en realidad arrancamos como una empresa súper luchona donde éramos por mucho los que menos financiamiento teníamos y sin marca. Probablemente nunca habríamos logrado salir de esa etapa de andar raspando centavos, hemos mantenido nuestro liderazgo en Indonesia a través de muchas cosas que hicimos del lado de la marca para que te des una idea de lo ingeniosos que tuvimos que ser en la competencia.
key_sentence: We were by far the underfunded player before achieving escape velocity.

text: And so we would have these actual physical locations where there would be lions of drivers essentially taking cash. And we eventually figured this out of like, okay, we'll work with a bank and integrate with an ATM network and all that. But in the early days we just did it ourselves of building essentially a mini at ATM network, which I think even that sounds too fancy of what it was it. Because it was literally a booth with a vault with cash in it.
speaker: Kevin Aluwi
context: Lenny asks Kevin for stories about how scrappy Gojek was in the early days. Kevin explains one of their biggest challenges: paying drivers when digital payments didn't exist in Indonesia. Since drivers needed to convert their digital earnings to physical cash, Gojek created physical cash distribution centers with vaults where drivers could line up to withdraw their money, essentially building their own primitive ATM network before proper banking integration was available.
text_ko: 그래서 기사님들이 줄 서서 현금을 주고받는 실제 물리적 장소들이 있었어요. 결국엔 은행과 협력해서 ATM 네트워크(ATM network)에 연동하자고 해결책을 찾았죠. 근데 초창기에는 저희가 사실상 미니 ATM 네트워크(mini ATM network)를 직접 만든 셈이었어요. 물론 그 표현도 과하게 들릴 정도예요. 실제로는 말 그대로 현금이 들어 있는 금고(vault)가 있는 작은 부스였거든요.
text_zh: 所以我们当时真的设了一些实体网点，每天都有很多司机排着长队来取现金。后来我们想明白了，觉得应该跟银行合作，接入ATM网络什么的。但是刚开始的时候我们就自己搞，基本上就是搭了个迷你ATM网络吧，不过说ATM网络都太高大上了。说白了就是搭个小亭子，里面放个保险柜装现金。
text_es: Y entonces teníamos estas ubicaciones físicas donde había un montón de conductores básicamente recogiendo efectivo. Y al final nos dimos cuenta de que, bueno, vamos a trabajar con un banco e integrarnos con una red de cajeros automáticos y todo eso. Pero en los primeros días lo hicimos nosotros mismos, construyendo básicamente una mini red de cajeros, aunque creo que hasta eso suena demasiado elegante para lo que realmente era. Porque literalmente era una caseta con una bóveda llena de efectivo.
key_sentence: It sounds too fancy to call it a mini ATM network.

text: I really don't like the idea of moats. Again, one of the concepts that gets thrown out a lot by strategy type folks of what's the moat of your business or your product? And usually people are looking for an answer like, oh, look at this capability or look at this feature or look at this distribution partner or all of those kind of things. And I don't believe that any moats are durable over time. Eventually with enough time all moats can be crossed.
speaker: Kevin Aluwi
context: Lenny asks Kevin about Gojek's philosophy of doing hard things instead of taking the easy path that most startups prefer. Kevin explains his contrarian view on competitive moats - the business advantages that supposedly protect companies from competition. He argues that traditional moats like special features or distribution partnerships aren't sustainable because competitors can eventually replicate them, but doing genuinely difficult things creates a more durable advantage.
text_ko: 저는 해자(moat)라는 개념 자체를 정말 별로 안 좋아해요. 다시 말하지만, 전략 쪽에서 자주 꺼내는 질문 중 하나가 “당신 비즈니스나 제품의 해자가 뭐예요?”인데, 보통 사람들은 “이 역량(capability)을 봐라”, “이 기능(feature)을 봐라”, “이 유통 파트너(distribution partner)를 봐라” 같은 답을 찾으려고 해요. 근데 저는 어떤 해자도 시간이 지나면 오래 버티지 못한다고 생각해요. 결국 시간이 충분히 지나면 모든 해자는 극복될 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我真的不太认同护城河这个概念。你知道，那些做战略的人总是爱问"你们业务或产品的护城河是什么？"通常大家会回答说，看我们这个能力啊，或者这个功能啊，或者这个渠道合作伙伴啊，诸如此类的。但我觉得任何护城河(moat)都不可能长久。时间久了，所有的护城河最终都会被跨越的。
text_es: La verdad es que no me gusta nada el concepto de "fosos defensivos" (moats). Es una de esas ideas que siempre sacan los de estrategia cuando preguntan "¿cuál es el foso defensivo de tu negocio o producto?" Y normalmente la gente busca respuestas como "mira esta capacidad" o "fíjate en esta funcionalidad" o "tenemos este socio de distribución" y cosas así. Pero yo no creo que ningún foso defensivo sea duradero. Al final, con suficiente tiempo, todos los fosos se pueden cruzar.
key_sentence: Moats get thrown out a lot, but all moats can be crossed.

text: And so we actually ran a fairly big private security operation for a fairly long time until it became common to have Gojek drivers do all of these things across cities. We actually ran this very operation intensive thing just to make sure that our drivers could be as safe as possible and it showed our commitment to the driver community, it showed our commitment that we cared.
speaker: Kevin Aluwi
context: Lenny is asking Kevin for more examples of Gojek doing hard things. Kevin describes how Gojek drivers faced violent resistance from motorcycle taxi mafia who controlled certain areas through intimidation and physical assault. Instead of treating drivers as independent contractors and leaving them to handle the violence alone, Gojek hired private security companies to protect their drivers and extract them from dangerous situations, demonstrating their commitment to driver safety.
text_ko: 그래서 저희는 사실 꽤 오랜 기간 꽤 큰 규모의 사설 보안 작전(private security operation)을 운영했어요. 도시마다 Gojek 기사분들이 이런 일들을 직접 하게 되는 게 보편화될 때까지요. 기사분들이 최대한 안전하게 일할 수 있도록 하기 위해서였고, 이렇게 운영 집약적인(operation-intensive) 일을 한 것은 기사 커뮤니티에 대한 저희의 헌신을 보여주고, 우리가 진심으로 신경 쓰고 있다는 걸 증명했어요.
text_zh: 所以我们其实搞了一个挺大规模的私人安保业务，而且做了挺长时间，一直到后来Gojek司机在各个城市做这些事情变得很普遍了。我们当时真的是花了很大力气在运营这个事情，就是为了确保我们的司机能尽可能安全，这也向司机群体表明了我们的态度，表明我们是真心关心他们的。
text_es: Y entonces manejamos una operación de seguridad privada bastante grande durante un buen tiempo, hasta que se volvió común que los conductores de Gojek hicieran todas estas cosas en las ciudades. De hecho manejamos esta operación súper intensiva solo para asegurar que nuestros conductores estuvieran lo más seguros posible, y eso demostró nuestro compromiso con la comunidad de conductores, demostró que realmente nos importaban.
key_sentence: Our operation intensive efforts showed our commitment to driver safety.

text: And so a lot of times I felt like I needed to understand, okay, what is this job? What exactly does it entail is, and seeing how bad I am at it allowed me to understand what good looked like. And so I held a lot of those roles just because I wanted to understand every part of the business as best as I could in order to then find somebody who could do it orders of magnitude better than myself.
speaker: Kevin Aluwi
context: Lenny asks Kevin about why he personally held so many different roles at Gojek, from CEO to performance marketer to driver. Kevin explains this wasn't just about being scrappy, but about understanding what excellence looks like in each role. Since experienced talent was scarce in Indonesia's early tech ecosystem, he couldn't easily hire proven professionals, so he first learned the roles himself to understand what good performance looked like before finding people who could do those jobs much better.
text_ko: 그래서 저는 많은 경우에 '이 일이 뭔가? 정확히 어떤 일을 포함하나?'를 이해해야겠다고 느꼈어요. 제가 그 일을 얼마나 못하는지를 보니까 잘하는 모습이 어떤 건지도 알 수 있었죠. 그래서 사업의 모든 부분을 가능한 한 잘 이해하려고 그런 역할들을 많이 맡았어요. 그래야 저보다 훨씬 더(orders of magnitude) 잘할 수 있는 사람을 찾아낼 수 있으니까요.
text_zh: 所以很多时候我觉得自己需要搞明白，这个岗位到底是干什么的？具体包括哪些工作内容？通过发现自己做得有多糟，我反而能看出什么叫做得好。所以我会亲自去做很多不同的角色，就是想尽可能地了解业务的方方面面，这样才能找到比我厉害好几倍的人来做这些事。
text_es: Y entonces muchas veces sentí que necesitaba entender, bueno, ¿qué es este trabajo? ¿Qué implica exactamente? Y ver lo mal que se me daba me permitió entender cómo se veía cuando estaba bien hecho. Así que ocupé muchos de esos puestos simplemente porque quería entender cada parte del negocio lo mejor posible para después encontrar a alguien que lo pudiera hacer muchísimo mejor que yo.
key_sentence: Understanding what exactly does it entail helped me find better talent.
